instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fast fans ( No sensor problems?)
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> shipped to me with previous repair work and bad <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> soldering.
Sorted out <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, cleaned flux in the ultrasonic. But the thing will not stop running fast fans despite passing apple internal hardware test. Ive checked HW monitor also and found all temperature sensors reading correctly, none are stuck .ect

The fans will start ramping up if left in boot menu.
Tried a known good shell and TPAD cable, tried new SMC, tried new EFI with clean ME region. I still have the same problem, Should i try ASD EFI on it just encase HW monitor and Apple hardware test is not picking up on the the issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fast fans ( No sensor problems?)
threads.message:
Problem resolved.
Turns out it was EFI related and i just did a terrible job at reballing a replacement SMC leading to a different thermal sensor issue. Lesson learnt, Retest after every repair attempt just encase.
Thanks
